body.p:
To His Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Govenor of Kentucky

Your Petitioner James McMillen states that at the April term 1861 of the city court of Louisville he was fined twenty five dollars for destroying the property of Mrs. Mae and twenty five dollars for assaulting her, Where he went to her house with some young men, at christmas, he had no notion to disturb her or her property and the complaint against him was that he raised a poker to strike her. He got on top the house when She refused their admittance and halloed down the chimney when it fell down and he fell off the house with it, injuring him, which Injury he repaired. It was not his inttention to Injure her or her house, which was not done only as stolen. He is unable to pay said fine the costs being as much as he can pay Wherefore he asks that the same be remitted
We the undersigned unite with petitioner in asking for a remission of his fine

M. Pyles
W. Emmit Garvin
John D Pope
J. G. P. Hore
Wm J Robrd
L P. Einrt.
Philip M Victor
W. W. Pope
R. S. Evans
L. T. Sedgwick
Jno A. McLaughlin
John Trohlhepp
Wm R. Jacob
S. L. Geiger
W G Reasor
I think the costs in these cases amount to more than the injury done.
